results.title: Windhorse
results.creator_credit: Paul Wagner, Thupten Tsering, Julia Elliott and Paul Wagner Productions
results.brief_description: Director Paul Wagner along with his cast and crew posed as tourists with video cameras to shoot this film on location in Tibet, avoiding Chinese secret police and security cameras in the process. The film follows a number of story lines that depict the plight of Tibetans at the hand of Chinese aggressors. Cast includes Dadon, Jampa Kelsang, Richard Chang, Lu Yu and Taije Silverman. Many cast and crew have asked that their names be withheld to protect themselves and their families. In Tibetan and Chinese with English subtitles.

results.title: Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, David L. Wolper, Stan Margulies, Quaker Oats Company and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description: This funny and inventive screenplay by Roald Dahl is based upon his best-seller “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.” Gene Wilder is at his zany best as Willy Wonka, owner of a world-famous sweet factory who offers the fabulous prize of a tour of his extraordinary premises to five lucky children. However, when the winners arrive to claim their reward, they are caught up in a series of incredible and exciting adventures as Willy Wonka tests their honesty. The Academy Award nominated soundtrack includes the hit “Candy Man”.

results.title: TV miniatures
results.credit_line:
Designed by Graham McGuffie
Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: These six miniature dioramas reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

constellations_primary.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_primary.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

results.description: Television didn’t just change the way we see the world; it changed the look and layout of our homes. Since TV arrived in Australia in the 1950s, how and where we watch TV evolved alongside its form and function. These six miniature dioramas, designed by Graham McGuffie and handmade by Emily Boutard, reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.
description_for_label: Television didn’t just change the way we see the world; it changed the look and layout of our homes. results.title: Seniority versus ability
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A sensitive issue in almost every plant: the question of whether a new, attractive job should go to the man who has served the company long and well, or to a younger man, low in seniority but who, in the eyes of management, represents a better long-term investment. A newly installed computer operation in a factory gives rise to such a dispute and, finally, to union grievance action.

results.title: Windrider
results.creator_credit: Vincent Monton, Paul D. Barron and Barron Films
results.brief_description: A windsurfer becomes obsessed with a woman who has been watching him surf. He undertakes a comical and unrelenting search for her which eventually wears down his resistance. Underlying his passion for her is the windsurfers’ determination to win the World Classic Windsurfing Championships for which he is preparing an unbeatable windsurfing rig. Stars Tom Burlinson and Nicole Kidman with Jill Perryman and Charles Tingwell.

results.title: TV news
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Media Probes”.
John Cameron Swayze, US television’s first national anchorman, examines how the drive for ratings has led to some dazzling newsroom packages. Highlights the notion of style in TV news programs and the image of the network for the audience, while touching briefly on the limitations of television as a news medium. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Soap operas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Media Probes”.
Takes the viewer behind the scenes to witness the production process that yields a daily television serial. In this case the American Broadcasting Commission’s ‘All My Children’. Examines the unique relationship that exists between some 35 million soap opera watchers and their favourite serials. Considers what is involved in the writing of the scripts. Suitable for upper secondary level.
